title: How to Glue a Finished Puzzle

steps.headline: Get liquid jigsaw puzzle glue.
steps.description: At your local arts and crafts store, you’ll see a choice between powder, spray on, and liquid glue. Unless you are comfortable mixing your own glue, it is best to choose the liquid variety. Pick a size that is suitable for the size of your jigsaw puzzle. You can also find jigsaw puzzle glue online. If you want to make your own glue, just mix one-part water with one-part white glue. Shake the mixture and you have puzzle glue! If you pick the 8 ounce (236 milliliter) bottle, you should be able to glue between 8 and 12 puzzles, depending on the size.

steps.headline: Use parchment paper to avoid gluing the puzzle to the table.
steps.description: Cut a piece of parchment paper one inch (2.54 centimeters) larger than the size of your finished puzzle. By using parchment paper, you can avoid gluing your puzzle to the work table. Although you may be tempted to use newspaper for this purpose, it is strongly discouraged. It will likely get stuck to your puzzle in the gluing process.

steps.headline: Slide the parchment paper under the finished puzzle.
steps.description: Since you don’t want to disturb your finished puzzle, it is best to carefully slide the parchment paper underneath the puzzle. Align the shape of the parchment paper with the shape of the finished puzzle. Place one edge of the parchment paper underneath one edge of the puzzle and gently slide it underneath the puzzle. You could ask a friend to hold the puzzle while you pull the parchment paper underneath.

steps.headline: Flatten the puzzle with a rolling pin.
steps.description: Since you’ll need the puzzle to be completely flat before applying any glue, you should make sure there are no edges sticking up or missing pieces. Use a rolling pin to press down any raised edges and to ensure the puzzle is completely flat.

steps.headline: Apply glue to the picture side of the puzzle.
steps.description: You can pour some glue directly onto the picture side of the puzzle. Alternately, you can use a brush to apply some glue to the puzzle. You should start with a small circle of glue, and then add more as needed. Avoid adding too much glue at once, since it can lead to swelling.

steps.headline: Spread the glue evenly across the surface of the finished puzzle.
steps.description: Use your paint brush to spread the glue evenly across the picture side of the puzzle. If you don’t have a paintbrush, you can use a business card or a piece of cardboard to spread the glue. Make sure you cover all of the pieces of the puzzle! At this stage, you may see some air bubbles. This is fine, since they will go away when the glue dries.

steps.headline: Let the glue bond and dry for 5 hours.
steps.description: Look on the bottle of glue to find out the drying time for your puzzle glue. Typically, it is around 5 hours. Let the puzzle dry completely.

steps.headline: Apply a second coat of glue.
steps.description: Use your paintbrush to apply a second layer of glue. Let it dry completely.

steps.headline: Apply glue to the back of the puzzle and let it dry.
steps.description: Slide the puzzle onto a piece of cardboard. Use the cardboard to flip the puzzle over onto the work table with the back of the puzzle facing up. Spread a thin layer of glue over the back of the puzzle. Let it dry completely. At this point, your puzzle should be sturdy and ready for display!

steps.headline: Purchase puzzle adhesive sheets from a crafts store.
steps.description: You can find puzzle adhesive sheets at your local arts and crafts store or online. Choose the size that is recommended for the size of puzzle you have finished. If you can’t find the correct size, you can always choose a larger size and then cut the sheets to size.

steps.headline: Lay your finished puzzle upside down on a clean work table.
steps.description: Sandwich the puzzle between two pieces of cardboard. Holding the puzzle between the two sheets of cardboard, flip it upside down. Remove the top piece of cardboard. Then, use a rolling pin to flatten the surface of the puzzle. Make sure there are no pieces sticking up!

steps.headline: Lay the adhesive sheets on the back of the puzzle.
steps.description: Starting on the left side of the puzzle, lay one sheet down at a time, working your way from left to right. Overlap the sheets by half an inch (1.27 centimeters), although more of an overlap is not a problem. Keep the edges of the adhesive sheets 1/8 inch (3.175 millimeters) away from the side of the puzzle.

steps.headline: Use a rolling pin to secure the adhesive sheets to the puzzle.
steps.description: Once the adhesive sheets are attached to the back of the puzzle, you can flatten everything out with a rolling pin. Then, you can remove the instructions that are attached to the back of the adhesive sheets.

steps.headline: Let the adhesive sheets bond to the puzzle.
steps.description: You’ll need to leave the puzzle for three hours, so that the adhesive sheets bond to the puzzle. After drying, you’ll be ready to display your puzzle!

steps.headline: Tack the puzzle to the wall with thumb tacks.
steps.description: Place the puzzle at an appropriate height and mark the corners with a pencil. Put the puzzle on the wall. Put a thumb tack in each of the four corners. Finally, erase the pencil marks.

steps.headline: Use foam core to mount your puzzle and prevent warping.
steps.description: Place your quarter inch (6.35 millimeter) foam core board on your work table. Put the finished, glued puzzle on top. Draw an outline around the edge of the puzzle, but try to mark a thin line that can be easily erased. Use a razor blade and a ruler to cut the piece of foam core to the correct dimensions. Spray the foam core with adhesive glue, and then place the puzzle on top. You may want a second set of hands to properly center the puzzle on the foam core. Spray the adhesive glue in a well ventilated area. The puzzle needs to be glued together prior to mounting.

steps.headline: Ask a crafts store to mount your puzzle to backer board.
steps.description: Mounting to backer board prevents warping. Your local craft store may offer this service, which involves attaching the puzzle directly to a piece of backer board with special adhesive.

steps.headline: Get the puzzle framed.
steps.description: If you plan to keep the puzzle on your wall for a long time to illustrate your accomplishment, you may prefer to get the puzzle framed. You could take the puzzle to a local framer. You could also pick up an inexpensive poster frame from a poster or photography store.
